ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: And what will convey to you what the Night-Comer is?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: How will you comprehend what the night star is?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: what do you know what the night-visitor is?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: Do you know what al-tariq is?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: And have you understood what the nightly arriver is?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: And what will make you to know what At-Tariq is
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: And what will make you know what the comer by night is?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: And what shall teach thee what is the night-star?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: - Ah, what will tell thee what the Morning Star is!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: and what could make you know what it is that comes in the night?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: And what shall make thee know that which the night-comer is?-
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: (and what will show you what is the nightly visitor?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: And what will explain to thee what the Night-Visitant is?-
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: And what will make you to know what At-Tariq (night-comer) is?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: What could let you know what the nightly comer is!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: But what will let you know what at-Tariq is?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: And what can make you know what is the night comer?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [86:2] And what will tell you what the night-visitor is? (mā’l-tāriq is a subject and predicate, standing as the second object of [the verb] adrā, ‘tell’; and what comes after the first mā, ‘what’, is the predicate thereof [of this first mā]) — this [statement] emphasises the magnificence of the ‘night-visitor’, which is explained in what follows. It is:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (Ah, what will tell thee) Muhammad (what the Morning Star is!) this is to arouse his astonishment.
